Title: Randomised Controlled Trial on Vascular Access Care for Haemodialysis

Background: This study aimed to update the 2015 guidelines on vascular access care for haemodialysis patients, focusing on patient-centered decision-making.

Methods: The guideline was developed collaboratively by a multidisciplinary team, including nephrologists, surgeons, nurses, radiologists, and patients. Systematic literature searches were conducted in MEDLINE, PUBMED, Embase, CINAHL, and The Cochrane Library up to December 2020. The Modified GRADE system was used to code the strength of recommendations and the level of supporting evidence.

Results: The guideline emphasizes a shift from the traditional "fistula first" approach to a more individualized decision-making process, considering patient preferences and clinical circumstances. Key recommendations include advising fistula formation for suitable patients and catheter access for very small children or short-term haemodialysis. The guideline also addresses complications, central venous stenosis, and the importance of planning and education.

Interpretation: The updated guideline provides a comprehensive framework for vascular access care, promoting informed patient choices and high-quality assessment. It highlights the need for a holistic approach, integrating patient individuality into decision-making processes.

Trial registration: Not applicable.

Funding: Not specified.
